verb.description: Make or shape (a metal object) by heating it in a fire or furnace and beating or hammering it.

examples: the two women forged a close bond
the country is forging a bright new future

verb.description: Produce a copy or imitation of (a document, signature, banknote, or work or art) for the purpose of deception.

origin: Mid 18th century: perhaps an aberrant pronunciation of force.
phrases: Beckingsale attacked on the strength sapping drag on lap 5 and only Stander could match him and together they forged ahead of the chasing trio.
the government is forging ahead with reforms
But local leaders are forging ahead with the stadium plan, no matter how many holes it has in it, with or without public support.
All are forging ahead with alternative fuel technologies.
Professors, recognizing their students' needs, either forged new and relevant material into their courses or steadfastly forged ahead with their planned syllabus.
